learning_outcomes.description: Identify musculoskeletal structures and peripheral nerves on human cadaveric specimens and/or images.
Describe the relationship between the anatomy and function of the skeletal, muscular and nervous systems in the various regions of the human body.
Relate the biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system, at the micro and macro levels of organisation, to human movement and mechanisms of injury.
Explain how skeletal and musculotendinous anatomy is affected by exercise, immobilisation, disease, and aging.
Integrate knowledge of the interdependence of normal anatomy and function to predict and explain functional deficits resulting from altered anatomy.

assessments.due_date:
Bone quiz 6/03/2026 2:00 pm

Tendon and Ligament quiz 13/03/2026 2:00 pm

Musculotendinous unit quiz 20/03/2026 2:00 pm

Each quiz will open 1 week prior to the due date.
assessments.task_description:
Bone Quiz (worth 5%)

  • This quiz consists of 10 multiple choice questions randomly selected from pools. Each attempt is timed 15 minutes.

Tendon and ligament Quiz (worth 5%)

  • This quiz consists of 10 multiple choice questions randomly selected from pools. Each attempt is timed 15 minutes.

Musculotendinous unit Quiz (worth 5%)

  • This quiz consists of 10 multiple choice questions randomly selected from pools. Each attempt is timed 15 minutes.

You may attempt each quiz as many times as you like prior to the submission time/date, with the knowledge that your questions are likely to change on each attempt. Your best attempt at each quiz will be marked. Marks are awarded for selection of the correct alternative.

Once each quiz closes, your answers will be marked, and a final score will be released via Blackboard Grade Centre.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of this assessment item will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: We recommend that you do not use the Blackboard Phone App nor a wireless network connection when completing this Blackboard assessment. Both are unstable and could affect your ability to complete your Blackboard assessment, by for example:
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This exam will test theory knowledge of Tissue biomechanics. Further details of the examination format will be provided on Blackboard during the semester.

The exam will be a closed book invigilated exam held on campus and undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. Students will be required to bring a laptop to the exam that meets the device requirements for Inspera. It is important that you check before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library. The Library website Get familiar with Inspera provides the latest information for students about using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard. 

You must bring your current UQ student ID card and present it on entry to the examination. If you do not have your UQ student ID card with you on the day of examination, Examinations Procedure clause 28 outlines acceptable student identification that may be presented at examinations. Students unable to produce the acceptable forms of identification (i.e. their current UQ student identification card or a document issued by the Student Centre) are NOT permitted to enter the examination room.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This exam will assess practical and theory content covered in REGIONAL ANATOMY - Upper limb.

The exam will be a written closed book on-campus exam in the Gross Anatomy Facility. The exam will comprise a combination of

  • identification of anatomical structures,
  • identification of surface anatomy features,
  • answering questions regarding anatomical structure and function.

Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams. 

This assessment task is to be completed in person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 4(23 Feb - 22 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Tissue biomechanics online pre-recorded lectures

Tissue biomechanics lectures are online pre-recorded lectures that students complete at their preferred time and pace before the corresponding 'Tissue biomechanics' tutorial. Each set of lectures will be made available 1 week (on Friday) prior to the related tutorial (the following Friday). Reading material will also be available through the UQ library.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05

Each set of lectures will be made available 1 week (on Friday) prior to the related tutorial (the following Friday). Reading material will also be available through the UQ library.

learning_activities.topic:
Course introduction [Langfield]

On campus in-person lecture to outline course aims & expected outcomes, learning activities, and assessment.
learning_activities.topic_description: Course introduction [Langfield] On campus in-person lecture to outline course aims & expected outcomes, learning activities, and assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Regional Anatomy GAF onsite induction

There is one mandatory GAF induction session scheduled in week 1.

Students must complete this induction to be permitted entry to the Gross Anatomy Facility for practical classes and exams.
learning_activities.topic_description: Regional Anatomy GAF onsite induction There is one mandatory GAF induction session scheduled in week 1. Students must complete this induction to be permitted entry to the Gross Anatomy Facility for practical classes and exams.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 4(02 Mar - 22 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Tissue biomechanics tutorials

Three in-person, on campus Tissue biomechanics tutorials are timetabled during weeks 2 to 4. Tutorials provide an opportunity for extensive student engagement. The Tissue Biomechanics tutorials include both interactive and collaborative activities whereby students further their understanding of course theoretical content. Reading material will also be available through the UQ library.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05

Reading material will also be available through the UQ library.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 13(16 Mar - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Regional Anatomy UQ Extend modules

Regional Anatomy theory content will be made available via Blackboard UQ Extend modules allowing you to self-pace your learning and complete formative exercises to receive personalised feedback and measure your understanding of course content prior to the related practical class. You should allocate a minimum of 3 to 4 hours per week to complete the UQ Extend content PRIOR to the related GAF practical.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Regional Anatomy UQ Extend modules Regional Anatomy theory content will be made available via Blackboard UQ Extend modules allowing you to self-pace your learning and complete formative exercises to receive personalised feedback and measure your understanding of course content prior to the related practical class. You should allocate a minimum of 3 to 4 hours per week to complete the UQ Extend content PRIOR to the related GAF practical.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 5 To Week 8(23 Mar - 26 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Upper Appendicular Regional Anatomy GAF practical classes

Practical classes are held in the Gross Anatomy Facility.

Practicals allow students to view and identify anatomical structure, normal anatomical variation, and specific pathologies. These highly interactive practical classes also provide opportunity for students to complete formative assessment tasks and to engage in discussions with academics and demonstrators to receive feedback on learning and further their understanding of course theoretical content.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Upper Appendicular Regional Anatomy tutorial

The upper appendicular regional anatomy tutorial is an interactive activity to provide opportunities to ask questions, check your understanding, and receive helpful feedback on your answers to study questions.
